greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: a(n) is the smallest positive d such that the n-th prime is the smallest prime p for which p+d is also prime.
comment: Except for n=1, A020483(a(n)/2) is the first appearance of the n-th prime. It is conjectured that a(n) always exists. a(386) is the first number which must be above 10^12.
link: J. K. Andersen, Prime gaps (not necessarily consecutive).
Mike Oakes, Ed Pegg Jr, Jens Kruse Andersen, Prime gaps (not necessarily consecutive), digest of 5 messages in primenumbers Yahoo group, Nov 26 - Nov 27, 2004. [Cached copy]
example: a(3)=6 because: The 3rd prime is 5. 2+6, 3+6 is composite, 5+6 is prime. 6 is the smallest such number.
results.author: _Jens Kruse Andersen_, Nov 28 2004
